whoIAm.title: Who I Am
whoIAm.p1: I'm a backend engineer with over a decade of experience building systems that need to be both robust and adaptable. What defines me is not just technical skill, but a deep commitment to honesty, presence, and care in everything I build.
whoIAm.p2: I don't play roles or hide behind jargon. I stay true to myself and bring full presence to my work, whether that's architecting a system, reviewing code, or mentoring a teammate. My strength lies in
whoIAm.p2Emphasis: transparency and the ability to face hard truths
whoIAm.p2End: , both in code and in collaboration.
whoIAm.quote: Mind brings clarity. Heart brings depth. Presence is my gift.

journey.title: The Journey
journey.p1: I graduated from LNMO (Laboratory of Continuous Mathematical Education) in St. Petersburg, where I explored over a dozen programming languages, from Pascal to OCaml, C, Haskell, and even Brainfuck. From my school years, I was involved in scientific research and presented at academic conferences. I placed 3rd in Mathematics at ICYS-2012 in the Netherlands, 1st at the St. Petersburg State Competition, and 3rd at the Baltic Science and Engineering Competition. In 2015-2016, I served on the youth jury for the Baltic competition. During this time, I worked on information decomposition algorithms, neural networks, and data analysis.
journey.p2: My path in development has been shaped by a principle:
journey.p2Emphasis: life is a continuous stream of experience that makes you stronger and wiser
journey.p2End: . Each project is an opportunity to learn, not just about technology, but about how systems serve people.
journey.p3: I used to approach problems from my head, chasing control and perfect solutions. Over time, I learned that true engineering happens when you stay present with the problem, listen deeply, and act from understanding rather than avoidance. The best architectures emerge when you respect both technical constraints and human needs.
journey.p4: From building dynamic EAV systems a decade ago to designing cloud-native Go microservices today, I've learned that sustainable solutions come from discipline, patience, and a willingness to stay with complexity until clarity emerges.

approach.title: My Approach
approach.p1End: . There are no shortcuts to quality. Every action, whether writing code, designing architecture, or reviewing pull requests, is an expression of care for the craft and for the people who depend on what we build.
approach.p2End: . Control is an illusion; you can't predict every edge case or prevent every bug. But you can take full ownership of your decisions, your code quality, and the trust you build with your team. This mindset has guided me through complex migrations, system redesigns, and moments where clarity only came after sitting with the problem longer than was comfortable.
approach.p3End: that work today while remaining adaptable for tomorrow. Clean architecture, well-tested code, and honest documentation aren't formalities; they are acts of care for future maintainers, including yourself six months from now when you've forgotten why you made that choice.
approach.p4End: to my work. Not just technical attention, but genuine engagement with the problem at hand. Great engineering happens when you stop avoiding complexity and start listening to what the system is telling you.

currentFocus.title: Current Focus
currentFocus.p1: Right now, I'm deepening my expertise in Go, exploring the intersection of backend systems and AI infrastructure, and building tools that bridge powerful technologies with practical human needs.
currentFocus.p2: I'm particularly interested in systems that need to be both robust and adaptable: microservices architectures that can evolve, databases that can handle dynamic schemas, and APIs that developers actually enjoy using.

beyondCode.title: Beyond Code
beyondCode.p1: Outside of programming, I'm interested in mindfulness practices, physical training, and the philosophy of continuous improvement. I believe that maintaining balance between focus and rest, intensity and ease, makes me a better engineer.
beyondCode.p2: These interests aren't separate from my work; they inform how I approach problems. Attention, patience, and presence are as important in debugging a complex system as they are in any other practice.

continuousLearning.title: Continuous Learning:
continuousLearning.text: Every experience is an opportunity to grow. I treat each project as a chance to learn something new about systems, people, or myself.

curiosity.title: Curiosity:
curiosity.text: Asking "why" and "how" leads to better solutions. I dig deep into problems to understand root causes, not just symptoms.

progress.title: Progress Over Perfection:
progress.text: Step by step, without rushing. Sustainable progress beats flashy shortcuts every time.

trust.title: Trust and Care:
trust.text: Building trust through reliability, clear communication, and genuine care for the people I work with and the systems we maintain together.

balance.title: Balance:
balance.text: Technical excellence matters, but so does pragmatism. Innovation is important, but so is stability. Finding harmony between competing needs is where real engineering happens.

website-builder.title: Dynamic Website Builder Platform
website-builder.description: A flexible website builder system from 10 years ago, featuring Entity-Attribute-Value (EAV) architecture for dynamic schema and multi-tenancy support.
website-builder.problem: Need for a website builder where users could create custom entity types and fields without database migrations, supporting multiple tenants with isolated data.
website-builder.solution: Implemented EAV (Entity-Attribute-Value) pattern with multi-tenancy support, allowing dynamic schema creation and type-safe value storage.
technicalDetails: EAV pattern for dynamic entity/field creation without migrations
Multi-tenancy with Company + ConnectionURL (separate databases per client)
Type-safe value storage with separate tables (Boolean, Integer, String, GeoLocation, Image)
Value storage design: Evaluated linking by ID to custom type tables vs direct type ID reference, chose separate tables for type safety and easier value retrieval
Visual layout engine with Section/Screen components
Dependency graph for object relationships - chose tree structure over cyclic graph for better scalability
Architecture decision: Entity can be used as field in only one parent entity (prevents circular dependencies)
Recursive table relationships: Field references Entity, Entity can reference Field (one-directional)
Dynamic filtering system for user-created entities
results: Users could create custom entity types without developer intervention
Achieved complete data isolation between tenants
Flexible enough to support various business domains
lessonsLearned: EAV pattern provides ultimate flexibility but requires careful query optimization
Multi-tenancy at database level provides strongest isolation guarantees
Type-safe value storage prevents data corruption in dynamic systems
Visual builders need strong dependency management to handle complex relationships
